title: FASTQ file format
abstract: FASTQ is a sequencing reads format. Each record is four lines: @header, sequence, +, and quality. Sanger FASTQ encodes PHRED quality with ASCII offset 33.

title: BAM and SAM
abstract: BAM is the binary, compressed form of SAM (Sequence Alignment/Map). BAM stores aligned reads and is indexed with .bai for random access.

title: VCF variants
abstract: VCF (Variant Call Format) stores genetic variants. Key columns include CHROM, POS, ID, REF, ALT, QUAL, FILTER, and INFO.

title: PCR basics
abstract: PCR (polymerase chain reaction) amplifies DNA using primers, DNA polymerase, dNTPs, and thermal cycling steps: denaturation, annealing, extension.

title: Mitochondria
abstract: Mitochondria generate ATP via oxidative phosphorylation. They contain their own circular mtDNA and are inherited mostly maternally in humans.

title: Retrieval-Augmented Generation
abstract: RAG combines retrieval and generation. A retriever fetches relevant passages, then a generator answers using those passages and should provide citations.

title: BM25 ranking
abstract: BM25 is a bag-of-words retrieval function. It scores documents using term frequency, inverse document frequency, and length normalization with parameters k1 and b.

title: TF-IDF
abstract: TF-IDF weights terms by term frequency and inverse document frequency. It is a strong lexical baseline for information retrieval.

title: Cosine similarity
abstract: Cosine similarity measures the angle between vectors. With normalized vectors, cosine similarity equals dot product.

title: Vector normalization
abstract: L2 normalization scales a vector so its Euclidean norm is 1. Normalization makes cosine similarity stable and comparable across vectors.

title: Chunking and overlap
abstract: Chunking splits text into windows. Overlap (stride < window) helps preserve context across boundaries. Tail policies include emit_short, drop, and pad.

title: Deduplication
abstract: Structural dedup removes duplicate chunks (same doc_id and span). Dedup prevents repeated context from dominating retrieval top-k.

title: FAISS index
abstract: FAISS is a library for efficient similarity search and clustering of dense vectors. It supports approximate nearest neighbor search.

title: Sentence Transformers
abstract: Sentence-transformers produce dense semantic embeddings. They enable semantic retrieval beyond exact lexical matches.

title: Prompt injection
abstract: Prompt injection attacks place instructions in documents. A safe RAG system must treat retrieved text as untrusted data and not follow those instructions.

title: Grounding and citations
abstract: Grounding means the answer is supported by retrieved evidence. Citations must map to returned contexts with valid spans.

title: OpenAPI drift
abstract: OpenAPI drift occurs when the implemented API differs from the published schema. Production systems gate drift by comparing generated schemas to checked-in schemas.

title: Rate limiting
abstract: Rate limiting protects services from abuse. Typical controls include per-IP and per-key limits and 429 responses when limits are exceeded.

title: GDPR and PII
abstract: GDPR regulates processing of personal data. RAG ingestion should detect and avoid exposing personally identifiable information (PII) in outputs.

title: MIT License
abstract: The MIT License is a permissive open-source license allowing reuse with attribution and a warranty disclaimer.

title: Stable identifiers
abstract: Index entries should use stable IDs derived from doc_id and chunk spans. Stable IDs enable reproducible baselines and cache keys.

title: Index fingerprint
abstract: An index fingerprint is a deterministic hash over index content and configuration (backend, tokenization, chunking, embedding spec). It supports regression gating.

title: Latency p95
abstract: p95 latency is the 95th percentile response time. Production RAG systems gate p95 for retrieve and ask to detect performance regressions.

title: Metadata filters
abstract: Retrieval should support metadata filters such as category or doc_id constraints. Filters reduce false positives and improve precision.

title: E2E tests
abstract: End-to-end (E2E) tests validate the full system behavior across boundaries. For RAG, E2E tests must gate retrieval quality and citation grounding.
